description:
Jellyfin works great for playing music across my wireless LAN, and it stays on my wireless LAN. It doesn’t require me to connect to a remote cloud account, or constantly push me to buy a subscription to a remote streaming service. I tried Jellyfin out after getting frustrated with Plex doing both of those things.

The server turned out to be easier to install than Plex, allowing me to set it up on my Raspberry Pi without hooking up a local display+keyboard or resorting to SSH tunneling. The initial import handled albums better. And best of all, I didn’t have to hook up my local server to a cloud account.

Oh, and the player works just fine.
summary: Plays music across my LAN and *stays* on my LAN

description: Great program -- best Linux Jellyfin client. Only annoyance is the cursor not disappearing when fullscreen.
summary: Web interface with MPV-level hardware decoding

description: Sadly not usable at the time
summary: Not launching in Fedora Wayland nvidia drivers (Blackscreen)

description: Works great as a client. No transcoding required.
summary: Works great as a client. No transcoding required

description: Not sure why or how, but won't even open. :(
It's worked really well. I just wish it would give you a media notification and media buttons support.
summary: A must have app for users of Jellyfin!

description: The Server and It's Media player took some time to get running but once it was up and running THIS NERD is impressed with the whole setup taking an old 2006 MacPro and Turning it into an Ubuntu 21.10 Media Server I Have been running it for over a month and not a issue to be found. Jellyfin and The Media Server Are Far Easier to Setup Then Plex or Emby

As stated above, it crashes on launch most of the time, but it is able to launch with enough tries. However, once it does launch, it works as expected. Overall, Jellyfin is a free and powerful Plex alternative.

Using Fedora 35
summary: Crashes on launch most of the time, but can work

description: Jellyfin has really been making a name for itself. A great open source project that has improved a ton the past years. Has plugin support and a good community. I switched exclusively to Jellyfin a while back from Plex and haven't looked back since.
Great open-source software to host your entire media collection in a sane and sensible way

I was quite enthusiastic to try this as an alternative to Plex. 
The reviews I found on the internet sang its praises and made setup sound so effortless.
You need the Jellyfin Server Service to run first for it to work though. 
I followed the steps at jellyfin.org (all terminal based) to get the server loaded and after four hours of troubleshooting gave up and trashed it all.
summary: Too difficult to get going for a novice

description: El servidor es muy sencillo de configurar y el cliente funciona perfecto.
